title: How to Make a Bog Garden

steps.headline: Dig out the area for your bog garden.
steps.description: It doesn't have to be large but it should be at least one metre in depth. Also, digging out lawn space is preferable as it's under-utilised space and the turf is handy for lining the bog. Keep the turf that you dig up.

steps.headline: Line the bog area.
steps.description: Once you've dug the hole, use black plastic pond liner to line it. Poke a few holes in the liner here and there.

steps.headline: Line the liner.
steps.description: Shovel over a layer of gravel and pebbles. Make this layer about 8 centimeter (3.1 in) high. Cover this with a layer of peat.

steps.headline: If you cut the bog space out of the lawn, place the pieces of turf back into the bog, facing upside down.
steps.description: If you used a different part of the garden, place those pieces back into the bog.

steps.headline: Fill the hole.
steps.description: Using decomposed plant matter, peat, fibrous plant material, and soil, fill the bog garden in.

steps.headline: Plant with suitable bog plants.
Keep watered using a hose.
steps.description: The moisture content will be retained much longer.

steps.headline: Weed regularly.
steps.description: Like any garden, weeds will grow and they need to be removed on a regular basis. Sedges can become a problem, as can buttercups, which will grow like weeds. Japanese iris will also grow like a weed.

tyn: Wet or damp garden space, shady
text:
Dig out the area for your bog garden. It doesn't have to be large but it should be at least one metre in depth. Also, digging out lawn space is preferable as it's under-utilised space and the turf is handy for lining the bog. Keep the turf that you dig up. Line the bog area. Once you've dug the hole, use black plastic pond liner to line it. Poke a few holes in the liner here and there. Line the liner. Shovel over a layer of gravel and pebbles. Make this layer about 8 centimeter (3.1 in) high. Cover this with a layer of peat. If you cut the bog space out of the lawn, place the pieces of turf back into the bog, facing upside down. If you used a different part of the garden, place those pieces back into the bog. Fill the hole. Using decomposed plant matter, peat, fibrous plant material, and soil, fill the bog garden in. Plant with suitable bog plants. Plants that might be ideal for your bog garden include: Hostas{"smallUrl":"https://www.wikihow.com/images/thumb/3/39/Make-a-Bog-Garden-Step-6Bullet1.jpg/v4-460px-Make-a-Bog-Garden-Step-6Bullet1.jpg","bigUrl":"https://www.wikihow.com/images/thumb/3/39/Make-a-Bog-Garden-Step-6Bullet1.jpg/v4-760px-Make-a-Bog-Garden-Step-6Bullet1.jpg","smallWidth":460,"smallHeight":345,"bigWidth":760,"bigHeight":570,"licensing":"

"} Keep watered using a hose. The moisture content will be retained much longer. Fertilise with a liquid fertiliser. Do this regularly. Weed regularly. Like any garden, weeds will grow and they need to be removed on a regular basis. Sedges can become a problem, as can buttercups, which will grow like weeds. Japanese iris will also grow like a weed.
sentences: Dig out the area for your bog garden.
It doesn't have to be large but it should be at least one metre in depth.
Also, digging out lawn space is preferable as it's under-utilised space and the turf is handy for lining the bog.
Keep the turf that you dig up.
Line the bog area.
Once you've dug the hole, use black plastic pond liner to line it.
Poke a few holes in the liner here and there.
Line the liner.
Shovel over a layer of gravel and pebbles.
Make this layer about 8 centimeter (3.1 in) high.
Cover this with a layer of peat.
If you cut the bog space out of the lawn, place the pieces of turf back into the bog, facing upside down.
If you used a different part of the garden, place those pieces back into the bog.
Fill the hole.
Using decomposed plant matter, peat, fibrous plant material, and soil, fill the bog garden in.
Plant with suitable bog plants.
